awd_titl_txt: Increasing Underrepresented Minorities in STEM: The 48th NOBCChE Annual Conference (Virtual)
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will support the participation of undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows at the national annual meeting for the National Organization for the Professional Advancement of Black Chemists and Chemical Engineers (NOBCChE) conference in 2021. This award is jointly funded by Divisions of Chemistry and Materials Research, both in the Mathematical and Physical Sciences (MPS) Directorate, the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences in the Biological Sciences (BIO) Directorate, and the Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, and Transport Systems in the Engineering (ENG) Directorate. The NOBCChE meeting has become an important conference to recruit diverse global leaders in the Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) fields and to create an inclusive environment in the broader scientific community. Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the NOBCChE conference will be held virtually this year. This award will provide the registration support to selected participants from populations that have been underserved in STEM. In addition, this award will enable the development of a robust online platform for participant engagement. 

This award will provide opportunities for participants to engage in four major areas of focus: 1) STEM technical and professional development; 2) networking and mentorship opportunities with STEM professionals; 3) exposure to prestigious minority role models in STEM; and 4) STEM career advancement opportunities. Student participants will interact with peers and professionals from industry, government, and academia to develop collaborations and to explore opportunities to pursue graduate degrees in the chemistry, chemical engineering and related disciplines. NOBCChE 2021 will also contribute to the knowledge of best practices for supporting student engagement via hosting this STEM meeting in a virtual environment and providing digital access to a repository of intellectual property pre- and post-conference.  The meeting will also serve to enrich the  technical, professional, and leadership skill sets of student attendees and students working on committees with other senior leaders on conference planning and execution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
48th Annual Virtual Conference

Outcome Report

The 48th Annual National Organization of Black Chemists and Chemical Engineers (NOBCChE) Conference was virtually from September 16-18, 2021. The conference theme was "Legacy of Resilience." The conference had approximately 685 attendees, consisted of 127 undergraduate and 239 graduate students supported by the National Science Foundation. These students participated in professional development sessions and presented technical posters and oral presentations covering areas of chemistry and chemical engineering. The students represented public and private universities inclusive of historically black colleges and universities, predominantly white universities, and other minority-serving institutions.

Students attending the conference virtually participated in four major areas: 1) STEM Professional and Technical Development; 2) STEM Executive Coaching, Mentoring, and Networking Opportunities; 3) Exposure to Prestigious Minority Models in STEM and 4) Academic and Professional STEM Career Advancement Opportunities. This conference provided a virtual environment for students to lean into their scientific advancement as the world continued to evolve around COVID-19. Highlights included a session sponsored by GEM Grad Lab encouraged students to pursue graduate degrees and provided insight into the graduate school application process and funding opportunities. The National Science Foundation Division of Industrial Innovation and Partnerships (IIP) in the Engineering Directorate leads several programs to translate fundamental research into market solutions. During the virtual conference, they offered a session on ?Invention to Impact" that explored NSF?s central role in accelerating the growth of the national ecosystem and explored specific funding opportunities. Students received free resume reviews, networking tips, and an opportunity to engage with the 69 virtual exhibitors. The Percy L. Julian award recipient was Dr. Malika Jefferies-El from Boston University, who discussed her chemical research career and life story. Several students received offers of internships and received interviews at the conference.

An evaluation of the student attendees indicated that the conference enhanced their identity as scientists and engineers. The students also experience an increased sense of belonging to a community of chemists and chemical engineers. The evaluation indicated that majority participants were female and attended predominantly white research universities. One-third of students were first-generation college students, and 60% of undergraduate students who completed the survey plan to pursue a doctoral program. The male students in attendance exhibited a greater sense of belonging than the female students. The report also noted sense of belonging among undergraduate and graduate students was similar.

These results indicate that the NOBCChE conference provides an environment that supports intellectual and emotional development of underrepresented students as they transition through their academic programs. This support system is vital to increasing student?s sense of belonging and long-term retention in chemistry and chemical engineering.

 


Last Modified: 12/16/2022
Modified by: Tyrslai M Williams
